org.grails.datastore.mapping.dirty.checking
[Groovy] Interface DirtyCheckable

interface DirtyCheckable

Interface to classes that are able to track changes to their internal state.

Authors:
Graeme Rocher
Since:
2.0

Method Summary
java.lang.Object getOriginalValue(java.lang.String propertyName)

Returns the original value of the property prior to when trackChanges() was called
boolean hasChanged()

@return True if the instance has any changes
boolean hasChanged(java.lang.String propertyName)

@param propertyName The name of the property
java.util.List listDirtyPropertyNames()

@return A list of the dirty property names
void markDirty()

Marks this instance as dirty
void markDirty(java.lang.String propertyName)

Marks the given property name as dirty
void trackChanges()

Indicates that the instance should start tacking changes.

 

Method Detail

getOriginalValue

java.lang.Object getOriginalValue(java.lang.String propertyName)
Returns the original value of the property prior to when trackChanges() was called
Parameters:
propertyName - The property name
Returns:
The original value

hasChanged

boolean hasChanged()
Returns:
True if the instance has any changes

hasChanged

boolean hasChanged(java.lang.String propertyName)
Parameters:
propertyName - The name of the property
Returns:
True if the given property has any changes

listDirtyPropertyNames

java.util.List listDirtyPropertyNames()
Returns:
A list of the dirty property names

void markDirty()
Marks this instance as dirty

markDirty

void markDirty(java.lang.String propertyName)
Marks the given property name as dirty
Parameters:
propertyName - The property name

trackChanges

void trackChanges()
Indicates that the instance should start tacking changes. Note that if the instance is dirty this will clear any previously tracked changes
